tiny.description: A blog app built using Python, Flask and MongoDB. The user can read, write and comment on blog posts. Basic search functionality is also included. In the future I would like to add the ability to like and favourite posts, like and dislike comments, and add tags to posts.
tiny.tech: Python, Flask, MongoDB, Jinja2, HTML5, CSS3 and Bootstrap.
tiny.learned:
• How to build a Flask app.
  • How to handle user authentication and sessions.
  • How to deploy an app to Heroku.

youtube-viewer.description: A simple YouTube viewer built using React. The user can enter a search term and get a handful of matching video results. I tried to replicate the general style of YouTube and make it responsive. I'm thinking about creating a more fully-featured clone of YouTube in the future!
youtube-viewer.tech: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, React, the YouTube API and Jest (for testing).
youtube-viewer.learned:
• How to interact with the YouTube API.
  • How to handle API responses appropriately within the context of React apps.
  • How to properly test React components in isolation using Jest.

recipe-box.description: A React app where the user can create, view, update and delete recipes using the browser's localStorage. I aimed to create a clean, attractive and responsive interface. This could be improved by storing recipes in a database on a server and developing an API to return the data.
recipe-box.tech: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, localStorage, React and Jest (for testing).
recipe-box.learned:
• How to create reusable React components.
  • How to interact with localStorage in a React app.
  • How to properly test React components in isolation using Jest.
  • How to test forms in React.
  • How to mock localStorage when testing.

matrix-digital-rain.description: An experiment with p5.js to recreate The Matrix digital rain effect. The inspiration for this project came from a YouTube video by The Coding Train (go and subscribe to his channel right now!). I plan on playing around with p5.js more in the future - I just need some ideas.
matrix-digital-rain.learned:
• How to create a p5.js 'sketch'.
  • Those funky symbols are called half-width kana characters.
  • A lot about randomising speeds and characters!

simon-game.description: A recreation of the retro Simon game written in JavaScript. The aim of this project was to create a game that was aesthetically and behaviourally very close to the original. The design is also responsive so works pretty well on small devices!
simon-game.learned:
• How to use the JavaScript Web Audio API.
  • How to manage many intervals and timeouts in JavaScript.
  • How to cope without jQuery (look Mum, no hands!).

jumpy-block.description: A Flappy Bird clone written using libGDX with an even simpler design. Desktop and Android versions are available. A cool feature of this clone is that it can also be played in portrait and landscape modes, I don't think this was possible in the original game.
jumpy-block.learned:
• How to develop a libGDX game for both desktop and Android.
  • A tonne about physics, game loops and sprites.
  • How to use Android Studio.

strimko.description: A JavaFX implementation of Strimko, a logic puzzle like Sudoku. The user can play and create puzzles of varying size and degrees of difficulty. Features include: hint highlighting, 'smart' solving to determine the solution to a puzzle (including its difficulty) and the pencil marks solving aid.
strimko.tech: Java, JavaFX, Guava, jUnit (for testing) and Gradle.
strimko.learned:
• How to build a JavaFX application (it's a lot nicer than Swing).
  • About Google's Guava libraries, these take the hassle away from carrying out a lot of common tasks in Java.
  • To embrace the lambda expression in Java 8.

twitch-status-viewer.description: A viewer written in JavaScript to display the status of Twitch channels. Channel data is pulled in using the Twitch API. The user can filter channels that are online or offline, and search channels by name.
twitch-status-viewer.tech: HTML5, CSS3, Bootstrap, JavaScript, jQuery and the Twitch API.
twitch-status-viewer.learned: • How to use the Twitch API to retrieve channel data.

blueprint-pong.description: A Pong clone written using libGDX with a blueprint design. The player can play against the computer at three difficulties: easy, medium and hard. Desktop and Android versions are available.
blueprint-pong.learned:
• How to develop a libGDX game for both desktop and Android.
  • About the physics/geometry of Pong.
  • How to create a challenging AI.
